NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
In the early eighteenth century, the poet and essayist Joseph Addison, drawing on imagery taken from the 23rd  psalm, wrote a text comparing the Lord's interactions with us to a shepherd preparing a pasture.  The text to this poem has become a beloved Christian hymn, but as a study in preparing an environment for learning and growth, it offers a remarkably apt analogy for thinking about instructional planning. 

 

The Lord my pasture shall prepare
And feed me with a shepherd's care;
His presence shall my wants supply
And guard me with a watchful eye;
My noonday walks He shall attend
And all my midnight hours defend.

Though in the paths of death I tread,
With gloomy horrors overspread,
My steadfast heart shall fear no ill,
For Thou, O Lord, art with me still;
Thy friendly crook shall give me aid
And guide me through the dreadful shade.

 

When in the sultry glebe I faint
Or on the thirsty mountain pant,
To fertile vales and dewy meads
My weary, wandering steps He leads,
Where peaceful rivers, soft and slow,
Amid the verdant landscape flow.

 

Though in a bare and rugged way,
Through devious lonely wilds, I stray,
Thy bounty shall my pains beguile;
The barren wilderness shall smile,
With sudden greens and herbage crowned,
And streams shall murmur all around.

 

A pasture is an adept analogy to guide us as we plan and structure our instruction.  Several BYU-Idaho faculty members have adopted the analog of pastures as a means for structuring their lesson plans.  Some of their comments can be viewed by clicking on the picture/video link below.

 

Pastures are used by herdsmen to allow their animals to graze while restricting them to a particular area. Fences keep the animals from wandering and give them a protected place to gain nourishment. Once the best foliage is exhausted within the enclosure, the animals are transitioned to a new pasture to avoid overgrazing of the field.

Like a shepherd who knows the best pastures for his sheep, instructors accompany and guide students through carefully chosen fields of inquiry. Some insights about lesson planning gleaned from this analogy are as follows:

  • Choose and Fence the pasture: When you determine your pastures, consider the following:  Is the pasture aligned with the learning objectives of the course? Will it provide learning that will build upon student preparation? Are key ideas, key questions and key problems clearly structuring the inquiry?  Explain the focus and parameters of your dialogue. Assign boundaries to the conversation so it has logical structure and a natural flow and momentum.


  • Find the gate: Just as important as defining what pasture to engage, is the decision of your approach.  Finding the gate means determining what question you want to answer as a result of your engagement with the material.  What is the problem you wish to resolve?  What polemic frames your approach to the new material? A book could be good material in a thousand different contexts; which context defines your reason for choosing the book or the topic? Is there a better approach to helping students capture these ideas?


  • Graze on what's green: It's easy to over-discuss or over-graze a topic. Don't graze one spot bare while leaving the rest of the green pasture untouched.  Encourage students to explore the key concepts of the whole pasture and then discuss the ideas from different angles and perspectives.


    1. Allow freedom within the boundaries: Provide people reasonable room to explore and deepen their understanding within the topic while at the same time structuring their experience within the pasture.  Random wandering is no better for real engagement than is a lock-step march through new material. Provide students both structure and freedom.


    2. Bring back the strays: When people wander out of boundaries with tangential comments or questions, guide them back with questions that redirect the conversation.  For those who insist upon walking the fence-line, remind them of the ideas or questions central to the inquiry.


    3.  Move on when the nourishment is exhausted: At a given point, the learning value of an activity becomes greatly diminished. Recognize this point of diminishing returns. Rather than pursuing every detail and loose end, close the gate behind you and discuss how the ideas explored in that pasture prepare students for the next pasture.


  • Transition between pastures: The relationship between the ideas in one pasture and those of the next is often just as important as the ideas within each pasture.  Be sure to lead the students from one learning pasture to the next in a way that emphasizes how the two are related. Sequence your pastures in a way that builds a logical momentum into your exploration. Below are several resource links for lesson planning using pastures.
